results.name: Largest prime divisor of n^2 - 1.
comment: Also the largest prime that divides either n-1 or n+1.

Størmer shows that a(n) tends to infinity with n. Schinzel shows that lim inf a(n)/log log n >= 2 and, using lower bounds for linear forms of logarithms, this inequality can be generalized for general quadratic polynomials, with 2 replaced by 4/7 for irreducible ones and 2/7 for reducible ones. - _Tomohiro Yamada_, Apr 15 2017
reference: K. Mahler, "Uber den grossten Primteiler spezieller Polynome zweiten Grades", Arch. Math. Naturvid. B.41, 1935, pp. 3 - 26.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
D. H. Lehmer, On a problem of Størmer, Ill. J. Math., 8 (1964), 57-79.
A. Schinzel, On two theorems of Gelfond and some of their applications, Acta Arith. 13 (1967), 177--236.

example: n=11: the largest prime factor of 10 and 12 is 5, therefore a(11) = 5.
